title: Acute Kidney Injury Care
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing acute kidney injury (AKI), focusing on assessment of kidney function, prevention of further injury, management of complications, and support of renal recovery in patients experiencing sudden deterioration in kidney function.

assessments.title: Kidney Function Assessment
points: Monitor serum creatinine and BUN levels
Calculate estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR)
Assess urine output (hourly measurements for critically ill patients)
Evaluate for oliguria (<0.5 mL/kg/hr for >6 hours) or anuria
Assess fluid balance (intake and output)
Monitor electrolyte levels (potassium, sodium, phosphorus, calcium)
Evaluate acid-base balance (pH, bicarbonate levels)
Assess for presence of proteinuria or hematuria
Evaluate urine specific gravity and osmolality
assessments.description: Comprehensive kidney function assessment helps identify the severity of AKI, monitor progression or resolution, and guide appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Etiology and Risk Factor Assessment
points: Identify potential prerenal causes (hypotension, hypovolemia, heart failure)
Assess for intrinsic renal causes (acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis)
Evaluate for postrenal causes (obstruction)
Review medication history for nephrotoxic agents
Assess for recent contrast media exposure
Evaluate for sepsis or systemic inflammatory response
Assess for history of trauma or rhabdomyolysis
Identify comorbidities that increase AKI risk (diabetes, hypertension)
Evaluate for recent surgical procedures
assessments.description: Etiology assessment helps identify the underlying cause of AKI, which guides specific interventions and prevention of further kidney damage

assessments.title: Complication Assessment
points: Assess for signs of volume overload (edema, crackles, dyspnea, weight gain)
Evaluate for hyperkalemia (ECG changes, muscle weakness)
Assess for metabolic acidosis (Kussmaul respirations, decreased pH)
Monitor for signs of uremia (nausea, confusion, pruritus, pericarditis)
Assess for anemia
Evaluate for bleeding tendencies due to platelet dysfunction
Assess for signs of infection
Monitor for hypertension
Evaluate nutritional status
assessments.description: Complication assessment helps identify and manage the systemic effects of AKI that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if left untreated

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Excess Fluid Volume related to compromised regulatory mechanism as evidenced by edema, intake greater than output, and abnormal electrolyte levels
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance related to renal dysfunction
definingCharacteristics: Not applicable as this is a risk diagnosis

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Decreased Cardiac Output related to altered afterload and preload as evidenced by dysrhythmias and altered heart rate

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved kidney function
indicators: Shows decreasing trend in serum creatinine levels
Maintains electrolyte levels within target range

goals.statement: Patient will maintain fluid and electrolyte balance
Patient will remain free from complications of AKI
indicators: Remains free from signs of uremia

interventions.title: Kidney Function Management
actions: Monitor serum creatinine, BUN, and eGFR daily or as ordered
Maintain strict intake and output monitoring
Implement fluid management as prescribed (restriction or replacement)
Avoid nephrotoxic medications and agents
Adjust medication dosages based on kidney function
Maintain adequate blood pressure to ensure renal perfusion
Administer diuretics as prescribed
Position patient to optimize renal blood flow
Prepare for renal replacement therapy if indicated
rationales: Regular monitoring allows assessment of kidney function recovery or deterioration
Accurate fluid balance monitoring guides appropriate fluid management
Appropriate fluid management prevents further kidney injury from hypovolemia or hypervolemia
Avoiding nephrotoxins prevents additional kidney damage
Medication adjustment prevents toxicity due to reduced clearance
Adequate blood pressure ensures kidney perfusion and prevents ischemic injury
Diuretics may improve urine output in volume-overloaded patients
Proper positioning prevents compression of renal vessels
Timely initiation of RRT prevents life-threatening complications
specialConsiderations: Consider underlying cause of AKI when planning interventions
Be aware that some patients may progress to chronic kidney disease
Consider contrast-induced nephropathy prevention for diagnostic procedures

interventions.title: Fluid and Electrolyte Management
actions: Monitor electrolyte levels (especially potassium, sodium, calcium, phosphorus)
Implement fluid restriction if indicated
Administer electrolyte binders as prescribed
Monitor daily weights at same time with same scale
Assess for signs and symptoms of fluid overload
Administer sodium polystyrene sulfonate or other potassium-lowering agents as prescribed
Implement dietary restrictions as appropriate (potassium, phosphorus, sodium)
Monitor cardiac rhythm for electrolyte-related changes
Administer calcium gluconate for severe hyperkalemia with ECG changes
rationales: Regular monitoring allows early detection and management of imbalances
Fluid restriction prevents volume overload in oliguric/anuric patients
Electrolyte binders reduce absorption of excess electrolytes
Consistent weight monitoring provides objective measure of fluid status
Early detection of fluid overload allows prompt intervention
Potassium-lowering agents prevent life-threatening hyperkalemia
Dietary restrictions reduce intake of electrolytes that kidneys cannot excrete
Cardiac monitoring allows detection of electrolyte-induced arrhythmias
Calcium gluconate stabilizes cardiac membranes in severe hyperkalemia
specialConsiderations: Consider more frequent monitoring for critically ill patients
Be aware that rapid electrolyte correction can cause complications
Monitor for dialysis disequilibrium syndrome in patients starting dialysis

interventions.title: Complication Prevention
actions: Implement infection prevention measures
Provide adequate nutrition while respecting renal restrictions
Administer medications to control uremic symptoms as needed
Implement bleeding precautions
Monitor for and treat hypertension
Provide skin care to prevent uremic pruritus complications
Administer bicarbonate therapy for severe acidosis as prescribed
Monitor for and treat anemia as indicated
Implement measures to prevent venous thromboembolism
rationales: Infection prevention reduces risk in immunocompromised state
Adequate nutrition supports healing while preventing excess waste products
Symptom management improves comfort and prevents complications
Bleeding precautions prevent hemorrhage due to platelet dysfunction
Hypertension control prevents further kidney damage and cardiovascular complications
Skin care prevents excoriation and infection from uremic pruritus
Bicarbonate therapy corrects severe metabolic acidosis
Anemia management improves oxygen delivery to tissues
VTE prophylaxis prevents thrombosis in high-risk patients
specialConsiderations: Adjust interventions based on AKI stage and progression
Consider multidisciplinary approach including nephrology, nutrition, and pharmacy
Be aware of psychological impact of acute illness and potential need for dialysis

expectedOutcomes: Shows decreasing trend in serum creatinine levels
Maintains electrolyte levels within target range
Returns to baseline kidney function or establishes new baseline

evaluations.statement: Has fluid and electrolyte balance been maintained?
expectedOutcomes: Maintains blood pressure within target range

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from complications of AKI?
expectedOutcomes: Remains free from signs of uremia

title: Chronic Kidney Disease Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing chronic kidney disease (CKD), focusing on slowing disease progression, managing complications, optimizing quality of life, and preparing for renal replacement therapy when indicated in patients with long-term kidney function impairment.

assessments.title: Kidney Function Assessment
points: Determine CKD stage based on eGFR (stages 1-5)
Monitor trends in serum creatinine and BUN levels
Assess for proteinuria (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio)
Evaluate electrolyte levels (potassium, sodium, calcium, phosphorus)
Assess acid-base balance (bicarbonate levels)
Monitor hemoglobin and hematocrit for anemia
Evaluate parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels
Assess vitamin D status
Monitor for signs of uremia in advanced stages
assessments.description: Comprehensive kidney function assessment helps determine CKD stage, monitor disease progression, and guide appropriate interventions for complications

assessments.title: Cardiovascular Assessment
points: Assess blood pressure (target <130/80 mmHg for most CKD patients)
Evaluate for peripheral edema
Assess for signs of volume overload (crackles, JVD, dyspnea)
Monitor lipid profile
Assess for symptoms of coronary artery disease
Evaluate for left ventricular hypertrophy
Assess for peripheral vascular disease
Monitor for dysrhythmias related to electrolyte imbalances
Evaluate exercise tolerance
assessments.description: Cardiovascular assessment is critical as cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in CKD patients

assessments.title: Nutritional and Lifestyle Assessment
points: Assess dietary intake of protein, sodium, potassium, and phosphorus
Evaluate fluid intake and restrictions
Assess nutritional status (albumin, pre-albumin, BMI)
Evaluate for protein-energy wasting
Assess physical activity level
Evaluate smoking and alcohol use
Assess medication adherence
Evaluate health literacy regarding CKD management
Assess psychosocial factors affecting self-management
assessments.description: Nutritional and lifestyle assessment helps identify modifiable factors that can slow CKD progression and improve quality of life

assessments.title: Renal Replacement Therapy Readiness Assessment
points: Evaluate for symptoms indicating need for dialysis initiation
Assess vascular access options for hemodialysis
Evaluate home environment for peritoneal dialysis suitability
Assess support system for home dialysis options
Evaluate transplant candidacy
Assess understanding of RRT options
Evaluate psychological readiness for RRT
Assess advance directives regarding RRT preferences
Evaluate financial resources for RRT
assessments.description: RRT readiness assessment helps prepare patients for transition to dialysis or transplantation when kidney function declines to end-stage

indicators: Maintains stable eGFR or shows slowed decline
Achieves blood pressure within target range

goals.statement: Patient will effectively manage CKD complications
Patient will demonstrate readiness for renal replacement therapy when indicated
indicators: Participates in decision-making regarding RRT modality

Expresses realistic expectations about life with RRT
goals.timeframe: Prior to need for RRT initiation

interventions.title: Disease Progression Management
actions: Administer and monitor effectiveness of antihypertensive medications
Implement ACE inhibitor or ARB therapy as prescribed
Monitor proteinuria and response to antiproteinuric interventions
Educate about smoking cessation
Implement diabetic control measures for diabetic nephropathy
Monitor and adjust medication dosages based on kidney function
Educate about nephrotoxic medication and substance avoidance
Implement appropriate fluid management
Coordinate care with nephrology team
rationales: Blood pressure control is essential for slowing CKD progression
ACE inhibitors/ARBs reduce proteinuria and slow progression
Reducing proteinuria correlates with slowed CKD progression
Smoking cessation reduces cardiovascular risk and may slow progression
Glycemic control slows diabetic nephropathy progression
Appropriate medication dosing prevents toxicity and kidney injury
Avoiding nephrotoxins prevents acute kidney injury episodes
Fluid management prevents volume depletion and overload
Specialist involvement optimizes evidence-based care
specialConsiderations: Monitor for hyperkalemia with ACE inhibitors/ARBs
Consider more aggressive BP targets for patients with significant proteinuria
Be aware of increased hypoglycemia risk with decreased kidney function

interventions.title: Complication Management
actions: Implement dietary restrictions (sodium, potassium, phosphorus) as appropriate
Administer phosphate binders as prescribed
Administer vitamin D supplements as prescribed
Implement anemia management (ESAs, iron supplementation)
Monitor and manage metabolic acidosis
Implement bone mineral disorder management
Monitor for and manage dyslipidemias
Implement measures to prevent and treat malnutrition
Administer medications to manage uremic symptoms as needed
Implement infection prevention measures
rationales: Dietary restrictions reduce complications from electrolyte imbalances
Phosphate binders prevent hyperphosphatemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D supplementation helps manage bone mineral disorders
Anemia management improves quality of life and reduces complications
Correcting acidosis may slow CKD progression and improve bone health
Bone mineral disorder management prevents fractures and vascular calcification
Dyslipidemia management reduces cardiovascular risk
Preventing malnutrition improves outcomes and quality of life
Symptom management improves comfort and function
Infection prevention reduces morbidity in immunocompromised patients
specialConsiderations: Balance dietary restrictions to prevent malnutrition
Consider non-calcium phosphate binders for patients with vascular calcification
Monitor for iron overload with supplementation

interventions.title: Patient Education and Self-Management
actions: Educate about CKD pathophysiology and progression
Teach medication management including purpose, dosage, and side effects
Provide dietary education with practical meal planning
Teach self-monitoring techniques (blood pressure, weight, symptoms)
Educate about importance of regular laboratory monitoring
Teach recognition of complications requiring medical attention
Provide information about RRT options
Educate about vascular access care if present
Teach strategies for managing fatigue and maintaining activity
Provide resources for psychosocial support
rationales: Understanding disease process improves adherence to treatment
Medication knowledge improves adherence and safety
Practical dietary education improves adherence to restrictions
Self-monitoring empowers patients and allows early intervention
Regular monitoring allows timely adjustments to treatment
Early recognition of complications prevents serious outcomes
RRT education allows informed decision-making and preparation
Proper access care prevents complications and preserves function
Activity management improves quality of life and function
Psychosocial support addresses emotional impact of chronic disease
interventions.frequency: Initially and with each significant change in condition or treatment
specialConsiderations: Adapt education to health literacy level
Include family members or caregivers in education
Consider cultural factors affecting dietary preferences and practices

interventions.title: Renal Replacement Therapy Preparation
actions: Provide education about dialysis modalities (hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis)
Educate about kidney transplantation options
Facilitate vascular access placement at appropriate time
Coordinate peritoneal dialysis catheter placement if chosen
Initiate transplant evaluation process if appropriate
Provide training for home dialysis if selected
Coordinate transition to dialysis center if center hemodialysis chosen
Assist with advance care planning discussions
Provide emotional support during transition to RRT
Connect patient with peer support resources
rationales: Education allows informed choice of RRT modality
Transplant information allows consideration of preemptive transplant
Timely access placement allows maturation before needed
PD catheter placement allows healing before use
Early transplant evaluation may allow preemptive transplantation
Training ensures safe and effective home dialysis
Smooth transition reduces anxiety and complications
Advance planning ensures care aligns with patient values
Emotional support helps adjustment to life changes
Peer support provides practical and emotional guidance
specialConsiderations: Consider patient's lifestyle, support system, and preferences in RRT planning
Be sensitive to cultural and religious beliefs affecting RRT decisions
Recognize that some patients may choose conservative management

Achieves blood pressure within target range
Maintains stable weight appropriate for health status
evaluationMethods: Review of laboratory values over time

title: Electrolyte Imbalance (Hyperkalemia) Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing hyperkalemia, focusing on assessment of potassium levels and cardiac effects, implementation of interventions to reduce serum potassium, prevention of complications, and education for patients at risk for recurrent hyperkalemia.

assessments.title: Potassium Level Assessment
points: Monitor serum potassium levels
Assess for laboratory errors or pseudohyperkalemia
Evaluate trend of potassium levels over time
Assess for hemolysis in blood samples
Evaluate potassium level in relation to acid-base status
Assess renal function (creatinine, BUN, eGFR)
Evaluate for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
Assess for other electrolyte imbalances
Evaluate medication profile for potassium-affecting drugs
assessments.description: Comprehensive potassium assessment helps determine the severity, cause, and context of hyperkalemia to guide appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Cardiac Assessment
points: Obtain and evaluate 12-lead ECG for hyperkalemia changes
Monitor for peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, widened QRS
Assess for cardiac dysrhythmias
Evaluate heart rate and rhythm
Assess for symptoms of cardiac effects (palpitations, syncope)
Monitor blood pressure for hypotension
Assess for signs of decreased cardiac output
Evaluate for chest pain or discomfort
Assess cardiovascular history for increased risk
assessments.description: Cardiac assessment is critical as hyperkalemia can cause life-threatening cardiac conduction abnormalities and arrhythmias

assessments.title: Neuromuscular Assessment
points: Assess for muscle weakness
Evaluate for paresthesias
Assess deep tendon reflexes
Evaluate for ascending paralysis
Assess respiratory muscle strength if severe hyperkalemia
Evaluate for gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, diarrhea)
Assess for fatigue
Evaluate for confusion or altered mental status
Assess ability to perform activities of daily living
assessments.description: Neuromuscular assessment helps identify manifestations of hyperkalemia that affect patient function and indicate severity

assessments.title: Etiology Assessment
points: Assess medication history (ACE inhibitors, ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, NSAIDs)
Evaluate dietary potassium intake
Assess for potassium supplements
Evaluate for cellular shifts (acidosis, insulin deficiency, beta-blockers)
Assess for tissue breakdown (rhabdomyolysis, tumor lysis, hemolysis)
Evaluate for adrenal insufficiency
Assess for decreased renal excretion
Evaluate for constipation (especially with potassium binders)
Assess for use of salt substitutes
assessments.description: Etiology assessment helps identify the underlying cause of hyperkalemia, which guides specific interventions and prevention strategies

goals.statement: Patient will achieve and maintain normal serum potassium levels
indicators: Demonstrates serum potassium within normal range (3.5-5.0 mEq/L)

Maintains stable potassium levels with prescribed treatment
Demonstrates improved renal function if applicable
goals.timeframe: Within 24-48 hours for acute hyperkalemia; ongoing for chronic management

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from complications of hyperkalemia
Patient will demonstrate understanding of hyperkalemia management and prevention
indicators: Describes medication effects on potassium levels
Identifies signs and symptoms requiring medical attention

interventions.title: Acute Hyperkalemia Management
actions: Administer calcium gluconate or calcium chloride IV for cardiac membrane stabilization if ECG changes present
Administer insulin with glucose to shift potassium intracellularly
Administer beta-2 agonists (albuterol) via nebulizer as prescribed
Administer sodium bicarbonate IV for significant acidosis
Administer potassium binding resins (sodium polystyrene sulfonate, patiromer) as prescribed
Prepare for and assist with dialysis if severe or refractory hyperkalemia
Implement continuous cardiac monitoring
Monitor serum potassium levels frequently during acute treatment
Assess for and manage hypoglycemia related to insulin administration
rationales: Calcium stabilizes cardiac membranes, protecting against arrhythmias
Insulin drives potassium into cells, temporarily lowering serum levels
Beta-2 agonists stimulate cellular potassium uptake
Bicarbonate corrects acidosis and promotes potassium shift into cells
Binding resins remove potassium via gastrointestinal tract
Dialysis rapidly and effectively removes potassium
Cardiac monitoring allows early detection of arrhythmias
Frequent monitoring assesses treatment effectiveness
Insulin administration can cause hypoglycemia requiring management
specialConsiderations: Calcium administration is temporizing and does not lower potassium levels
Insulin/glucose and albuterol effects are temporary (2-6 hours)
Monitor for rebound hyperkalemia after temporary treatments

interventions.title: Ongoing Hyperkalemia Management
actions: Administer loop or thiazide diuretics as prescribed
Implement dietary potassium restrictions
Administer oral potassium binders as prescribed
Review and adjust medications that affect potassium levels
Monitor renal function and urine output
Implement fluid management as appropriate
Monitor acid-base balance
Administer sodium bicarbonate for chronic metabolic acidosis as prescribed
Schedule regular laboratory monitoring of potassium levels
Coordinate with nephrology for patients with kidney disease
rationales: Diuretics enhance renal potassium excretion
Dietary restriction reduces potassium intake
Oral binders reduce potassium absorption from gut
Medication adjustment addresses iatrogenic causes
Renal function affects potassium excretion
Appropriate hydration supports renal potassium excretion
Acidosis correction helps normalize potassium distribution
Chronic bicarbonate therapy may help with potassium control
Regular monitoring allows timely intervention
Specialist involvement optimizes management in complex cases
interventions.frequency: Daily and as needed based on potassium levels
specialConsiderations: Balance potassium restriction with overall nutritional needs
Consider medication interactions with potassium binders
Be aware of constipation risk with some potassium binders

interventions.title: Patient Education
actions: Teach about foods high in potassium and appropriate alternatives
Educate about medications that affect potassium levels
Instruct on proper use of prescribed potassium binders
Teach signs and symptoms of hyperkalemia requiring medical attention
Educate about importance of regular laboratory monitoring
Instruct on proper use of diuretics if prescribed
Teach about avoiding salt substitutes containing potassium
Educate about proper hydration
Instruct on medication adherence importance
Provide written materials about potassium management
rationales: Dietary knowledge allows appropriate food choices
Medication knowledge prevents iatrogenic hyperkalemia
Proper binder use maximizes effectiveness and minimizes side effects
Symptom recognition allows early intervention
Regular monitoring prevents severe hyperkalemia
Proper diuretic use enhances potassium excretion
Salt substitutes can be significant source of potassium
Adequate hydration supports renal potassium excretion
Medication adherence prevents fluctuations in potassium levels
Written materials reinforce verbal teaching
interventions.frequency: Prior to discharge and at follow-up visits
specialConsiderations: Adapt education to health literacy level
Consider cultural dietary preferences when providing alternatives
Include family members or caregivers in education
